Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Theory-guided design of a novel chemical looping process for methane coupling using hydrogen storage materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1454384 - Grabow

An economically viable process to transform abundant natural gas, primarily composed of methane (CH4), to higher value products (e.g. ethane or ethylene) could revolutionize the chemical industry. The prevailing challenge in all processes using CH4 feedstock is activating the strong C-H bond, which is typically done in the presence of an oxidizing agent and requires high temperatures for activation coincidentally leading to unselective reaction pathways. The primary goal of this project is to develop a new chemical looping process for selective CH4 coupling in the absence of oxygen using hydrogen storage materials. First principles calculations will guide the selection of promising hydrogen storage materials and subsequent reaction/diffusion modeling will further narrow down the group of candidate materials. Laboratory scale experimental testing is used to verify the model predictions and to optimize the operating conditions.

Recent technological developments in hydraulic fracturing (fracking) to produce shale gas provide a huge incentive to develop commercially viable methane conversion processes to benefit the U.S. economy. Utilization of large shale and tight gas reservoirs in the U.S. and many other parts of the world have led to an increased interest in its main component, methane (CH4). As of 2011 the proven natural gas reserves total 208.4 trillion cubic meters worldwide, of which 7.72 trillion cubic meters are located in the U.S. Natural gas is also a significant byproduct during oil production and an estimated 150 billion cubic meters are being flared annually.Traditional uses of methane include electricity generation (combustion) and conversion to syngas, a mixture of CO and H2, using steam reforming over Ni-based catalysts.However, the potential for methane as a feedstock for the production of liquid hydrocarbons and useful chemicals has not yet been fully realized and an economically viable methane to higher value chemicals upgrade process could revolutionize the energy sector and chemical industry. The pervasive challenge of using CH4 as feedstock is activating the very strong C-H bond (435 kJ/mol). Currently implemented processes utilizing CH4 require high temperatures and the presence of oxygen-containing species (e.g. O2, H2O, CO2). These processes work well for the generation of syngas, which can subsequently be converted to higher hydrocarbons in a Fischer-Tropsch synthesis reactor. However, the direct conversion of CH4 to C2+ species remains one of the grand challenges in the chemical industry. Oxidative coupling of methane (OCM), could potentially address this challenge, but decades of intensive research have not been able to solve the issue of carbon selectivity. The competing combustion reaction consumes a large fraction of the CH4 feedstock and the high reactivity of the CH3 intermediates in the presence of O2 presents an insurmountable obstacle. In this research project a new process for methane coupling is proposed, which uses chemical looping and hydrogen storage materials to separate the carbon and oxygen atoms in order to avoid the formation of undesired carbon monoxide (CO) or carbon dioxide (CO2). The proposed research activities will be integrated with broad-reaching educational efforts at the K-12, undergraduate, graduate and professional level to broaden the participation of minority students and increase the retention of at-risk students. Partnerships with Marlo Diosomito and two economically disadvantaged Title-1 high schools in the Cypress Fairbanks ISD that the PI supervises will be leveraged to generate more interest in STEM disciplines and increase the representation of students from low-income families. UH is a designated Hispanic-Serving Institution and has the most ethnically balanced student body of all major research institutions in the U.S.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To capitalize on the abundance of shale and natural gas in the United States it is necessary to go beyond the established technologies of using it for heating, electricity and steam-reforming. The light alkanes contained in natural gas have the potential to replace other feedstock in chemical manufacturing, but strong C-H bonds present a large obstacle for their conversion to value-added chemicals. The most common strategy to provide a chemical driving force for activating C-H bonds is the addition of oxygen, which reacts with hydrogen to form water. Unfortunately, oxygen may also react with carbon to form CO2, essentially leading to the thermodynamically preferred complete combustion of small hydrocarbons.

To valorize small hydrocarbons while avoiding their unselective combustion, we have investigated strategies where the direct contact of carbon and oxygen is avoided. Our initial focus was on chemical looping concepts where methane as model compound was activated on a hydride-forming metal. The remaining CH3 and CH2 fragments may recombine to form ethane or ethene as desired products. Here, the metal serves as hydrogen storage material and can be regenerated in a second reactor with oxygen. While this unconventional method for upgrading methane remains promising, we found in our combined experimental and computational study that the hydrogen uptake from methane was either prohibitively slow or so fast that the reaction resulted in a metal-hydride covered in coke.

The fundamental trade-off between activity and selectivity can be overcome with special, isolated active site arrangements. For instance, we were able to computationally confirm that isolated palladium atoms in the surface of gold are catalyzing the activation of methane, while forming weakly bound methyl fragments that can undergo selective transformations. Meanwhile, we have extended this concept to the dehydrogenation of methanol and formic acid. A critical aspect is the stability of such special sites. To this end, we developed a hybrid model inspired by physics and augmented it with machine-learning techniques to predict the stability of dilute surface alloys that feature isolated atoms in the surface, subsurface, as adatoms, or as agglomerated small clusters. The model works for 784 binary alloys and is easily extendable to new geometries and can be adopted to account for a reactive gas phase environment.

Finally, we also used quantum chemical simulation tools to explore electrochemical concepts for C-H bond activation building on prior work in the area of high temperature, molten carbonate fuel cells. On the cathode side oxygen reacts with CO2 to form carbonate ions, which diffuse to the anode, where they react with methane. We find that carbonate ions are capable of accepting protons from methane over a nickel-oxide anode. Moreover, the activation barriers are sensitive to the applied electric field, suggesting that the applied potential can be used to further tune the reactivity. By controlling the electric current, the delivery of oxygen can be controlled and over-oxidation avoided.

The ability to selectively activate C-H bonds is of general importance and considering the abundance of natural gas resources and the underutilized potential of converting small hydrocarbons into useful chemicals and fuels, a large socioeconomic benefit and improved energy security can be derived from this project. Specific outcomes of this proposal are of interest to major refineries, hydrocracking plants, and chemical companies that are aiming to increase their feedstock flexibility, a key component for success in today’s fast changing petrochemical markets. This grant directly supported the training of three graduate students and three undergraduate students at the University of Houston. Two additional graduate students were able to collaborate on this project. Four of the participants had a minority background in STEM disciplines. One of the domestic graduate students had to opportunity for an industrial internship within the NSF INTERN initiative, which further contributed to their professional training as well as keeping the project relevant to industry.
